claim_reports.verdict_summary: Multiple high-reliability sources, including the IPCC report and articles from reputable outlets like NPR and BBC, emphasize the critical need to limit global warming to 1.5 degrees Celsius to prevent severe climate consequences, aligning with the claim.

supports.title: What's in a number? The meaning of the 1.5-C climate threshold
supports.evidence_summary: The article discusses the significance of the 1.5°C climate threshold, which is recognized by the Paris Agreement as a critical limit to prevent severe climate consequences, indicating that scientists warn about the need to stay below this threshold.
supports.snippet: Global average temperature was more than 1.5 degrees Celsius warmer than the pre-industrial average for several months in late 2023.

supports.title: Global Warming of 1.5 ºC —
supports.evidence_summary: The article discusses the significance of the 1.5°C threshold for global warming, emphasizing that it is a target agreed upon by countries in the Paris Agreement to mitigate severe climate impacts. It highlights the consensus among scientists regarding the need to limit warming to this level to avoid catastrophic consequences.
supports.snippet: An IPCC special report on the impacts of global warming of 1.5 °C above pre-industrial levels and related global greenhouse gas emission pathways.

supports.title: How the climate would change if the world warms over 1.5 degrees
supports.evidence_summary: The article discusses the significance of the 1.5°C threshold for global warming, emphasizing that exceeding this limit could lead to severe consequences, such as the loss of coral reefs and other ecological impacts, which aligns with the claim about the need to limit warming to avoid climate breakdown.
supports.snippet: At 1.5 degrees Celsius, it's likely that 70 to 90% of coral reefs will die off worldwide. At 2 degrees Celsius of warming, 99% are lost.

supports.evidence_summary: The evidence strongly supports the claim that limiting global warming to 1.5 degrees Celsius is crucial to mitigate severe climate breakdown consequences, as it emphasizes the need for urgent action to reduce greenhouse gas emissions to avoid catastrophic impacts.
